Show the Alphabet Cards for the letters
. Say the letter aloud and invite children to repeat.
makes the /u/ sound you hear in the word
makes the /u/ sound you hear in
Show the Alphabet Cards for the letters Vv. Say the letter aloud and invite children to repeat.
makes the /v/ sound you hear in the word
The letter v makes the /v/ sound you hear in
Today we will read a book about the letters
and a book about the letters
Touch your nose when you hear a word that begins with the /u/ sound.
Tap your shoulder when you hear a word that begins with the /v/ sound.
Practice Forming the Letters Uu and Vv
Help children practice forming the letters
. Model writing the letters. Invite children to practice writing the letters
stop at each word that begins with the letter
. Invite children to say /u/ and the word that begins with
. For children who need assistance, invite them to trace letters in trays of salt or sand.

After reading each story, challenge children to try to remember all the words that begin with the target sound and letter. Then ask them to saay any other words they know that begin with that letter and sound.
Be aware that some children whose first language is Spanish may pronounce the letters
alike. Take extra time, as needed, to review the sounds those letters make in English, both in isolation and in the context of a picture word.

To help children with auditory discrimination challenges, exaggerate the movements of your mouth as you form each letter sound, being mindful of your tongue and lip positions. Do this while saying the sound in isolation and again as you say the sound within the picture word. Invite children to move their mouths in the same way as they make the letter sound.

drawing and writing supplies, Hello Goodbye Dog

. Revisit feelings Vocabulary Card. We read about Moose’s feelings. What feelings did Moose have when Zara went to school? We read about Zara’s feelings. What feelings did Zara have when she saw Moose at school? We read about Mrs. Perkins’s feelings. What feelings did Mrs. Perkins have when she saw Moose in class?
Sometimes our feelings are the same. Sometimes our feelings change. We’re going to talk about how Moose’s feelings change throughout
Today we are going to draw about Moose’s feelings.
Place the drawing supplies in front of you. Turn to page 3 in
I’m drawing Moose with a smile because she’s happy to be with Zara. Let’s see other feelings that Moose has throughout this story.
How is Moose feeling? How do you know Moose is feeling this way?

Provide drawing supplies. Have children draw Moose looking frustrated. Continue through the book, stopping where Moose’s feelings change from page to page. Have children discuss her change in feelings each time. Have children draw more faces of Moose, showing different kinds of feelings.
Have children share the details in the pictures that help them show how Moose is feeling. Invite children to reflect on the drawing feelings activity.
Are all feelings the same? Let’s see how many feelings we can name!
Walk children through the drawing activity by drawing a third picture of Moose together. Ask supporting questions about the facial details in order to help children name the feeling being shown.
Challenge children to identify feelings they see in the other characters, such as
what do you think Zara’s mom is feeling?
Invite children to name more feelings and explain why the characters may be feeling a certain way throughout the story.
Help multilingual learners identify the English names for feelings. Take time, as needed, to review feelings such as

Be aware that discussing feelings can be a potentially sensitive topic for children. Allow for opportunities for children to share about their feelings but understand that children may not want to share. Help children feel safe in their learning environment and give them the freedom to share what they choose to share.
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
. We saw how Moose missed Zara when Zara went to school. Moose became a therapy dog!
A therapy dog goes to a special school to learn how to help others. Therapy dogs are allowed to go to places other dogs can’t go, like school!
In this activity, we are going to help Moose graduate from dog therapy school! We are going to find the picture that matches something Moose was tested on in dog therapy school.
Place Activity Card with the photo of the dog with the graduation cap face up. Keep the remaining cards face down.
Begin by holding up the photo of the dog in the graduation cap and asking the questions on the back of the card, offering support or extra challenge as need. Flip over all the other Activity Cards.
Which card shows a friendly dog?

Continue the activity, naming each thing Moose was tested on: lying down, knowing how to stay, being good with children, and knowing how to be around wheelchairs. Ask children to look at the Activity Cards and choose each card that matches the skill. Use the questions on the back of the cards.
Invite children to talk about what they learned about therapy dogs. Have children share how therapy dogs can help people. Provide extra support and prompting as needed.
To simplify the activity, begin with each dog training picture card face up under the dog graduation card. Name each activity, asking children to name them after you.
Work together to write a sentence about each picture, focusing on adding some description to each sentence. Encourage children to assist with ending punctuation for each sentence.

Encourage children to use the Clifford puppet to model what the Activity Card represents. Provide language to support what the child is showing with the puppet, then encourage children to repeat the words along with you as you say them a second time.
Assist children by beginning with yes or no questions about the card, then follow up to encourage the child to model sentences after you, such as:
Say this after me: The dog learns to sit down.
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
Today we read the informational poster “What Pets Need” and talked about how to keep our pets healthy.
In this activity, we will practice taking care of our pets! We will each make a pet out of play clay. Then we will show how we take care of our pets.
Model how to quickly form the play clay into a pet shape. Then, provide each child with clay. Have each child create their own pet.
Pets need healthy food. Let’s give our pet healthy food.
Pantomime giving your pet food. Have children “feed” their pets.

Continue the activity, having individual children name what pets need and then have the group pantomime the action with their pets. Ask children what else pets need. Prompt children to look at “What Pets Need” as necessary.
Talk about what pets need to stay healthy.
Why do pets need these things to stay healthy?
Provide prompting and support as necessary.
Read “What Pets Need” item by item when children need extra support to name what pets need.
Challenge children to explain why each need mentioned in “What Pets Need” is essential to good pet care.
Why is it important to keep our pets healthy?
Help multilingual learners identify the English names for some common pets, such as
Assist children as needed in making the play-clay pet. Ask the child to tell you the pet they want to create and have them participate to the best of their ability as you shape it.
